          performance.mark('gtm.start');
          (function (w, d, s, l, i) {
            w[l] = w[l] || [];
            w[l].push({ 'gtm.start': new Date().getTime(), event: 'gtm.js' });
            var f = d.getElementsByTagName(s)[0],
                j = d.createElement(s),
                dl = l != 'dataLayer' ? '&l=' + l : '';
            j.async = true;
            j.src = 'https://www.googletagmanager.com/gtm.js?id=' + i + dl;
            j.onload = function () {
              performance.mark('gtm.end');
              performance.measure('gtm', 'gtm.start', 'gtm.end');
            };
            f.parentNode.insertBefore(j, f);
        })(window, document, 'script', 'dataLayer', 'GTM-M36RG8PT');

Their goals range from espionage for technology advancement and disruption of critical infrastructure to for-profit theft of trade secrets and supporting a political agenda. You no longer have a malware problem, you have an adversary problem, and you must incorporate an intelligence-driven approach to your security strategy. \r\n \r\nDuring this CrowdCast, you will learn class="metadata Metadata_root__oCstk" data-cy="metadata"><h1 class="Heading_heading__3MAvZ Heading_h1__3k7S2 title Title_root__svkHQ">CrowdCasts Monthly: You Have an Adversary Problem</h1><div class="stats Stats_root__p_BoZ"><time dateTime="2013-10-16 14:09:38 UTC">Oct 16, 2013</time><span class="Stats_bullet__DbT30"></span><span class="Text_root__is73U Text_weight-strong__yEO2S Text_secondary__EPWj0 Text_medium__rk8Tn Likes_root__WVQ1_ text" style="-webkit-line-clamp:0" tabindex="0">6 likes</span><span class="Stats_bullet__DbT30"></span><span class="Text_root__is73U Text_weight-strong__yEO2S Text_secondary__EPWj0 Text_medium__rk8Tn Likes_root__WVQ1_ text" style="-webkit-line-clamp:0" tabindex="0">21,308<!-- --> <!-- -->views</span></div><div class="author Author_root___6Bx5"><a data-cy="author-link" class="Author_link___lVxw ellipsis" title="CrowdStrike" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike"><div class="Avatar_root__GNWHY" style="width:24px;height:24px;line-height:24px"><img class="Avatar_image__Bbtll" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/profile-photo-CrowdStrike-48x48.jpg?cb=1523357406" alt="CrowdStrike" loading="lazy" decoding="sync"/></div><span>CrowdStrike</span></a></div><div class="description Description_root__kt4uq Description_clamped__PaV_1"><div class="Description_wrapper__hYE9_" data-cy="document-description"><p>You Have an Adversary Problem. Who&#x27;s Targeting You and Why? 
 
Nation-States, Hacktivists, Industrial Spies, and Organized Criminal Groups are attacking your enterprise on a daily basis. Their goals range from espionage for technology advancement and disruption of critical infrastructure to for-profit theft of trade secrets and supporting a political agenda. You no longer have a malware problem, you have an adversary problem, and you must incorporate an intelligence-driven approach to your security strategy. 
 
During this CrowdCast, you will learn how to:

    Incorporate Actionable Intelligence into your existing enterprise security infrastructure 
    Quickly understand the capabilities and artifacts of targeted attacked tradecraft 
    Gain insight into the motivations and intentions of targeted attackers
    Make informed decisions based off of specific threat intelligence
<button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_primary__K25Gq Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Description_less__BvWbY Description_hidden__a9QZJ" data-testid="button" aria-label="Read less"><span>Read less</span></button></p></div><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_primary__K25Gq Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Description_more__ChrRK"  " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-3-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-3-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/75/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-3-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-3-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide4" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:959 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-3" alt="@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

Today’s Speakers
MATT DAHL |
SENIOR ANALYST/ LEGAL COUNSEL
Cyber threat analyst focused on targeted intrusion activity

specific adversary activity

4

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/75/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide5" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:959 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-4" alt="@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

Adversaries are humans
Targeted Attackers:

WHO ARE THE
ADVERSARIES?

Motivation can range from disruption,
theft, to even destruction
They need to get in
They will likely need to move laterally

Spray and Pray (Prey):
They don’t care who they target
(sometimes what)
The more they compromise the
more they win
Motivation can range from disruption,
theft, to even destruction
2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

Adversary Categorization
CATEGORIZATION| Adversary Groups

1

Tactics, Techniques, and Practices

2

Never assume relationships exist
Between indicators

3

Recognize adversaries are constantly changing

4

But RECOGNIZE they are HUMAN

CATEGORIZATION

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-17-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-17-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/75/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-17-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-17-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide18" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:959 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-17" alt="@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

Target Sectors: Aerospace; Defense;
Energy; Government; Shipping;
Technology; Telecommunications

WHO IS
GOBLIN PANDA?

Delivery: Spearphishing
Malware: HttpTunnel (AV detection = Zegost)
Mutexes: HttpTunnel@@ or Http@@@

C2 Indicators: vnpt.conimes.com;
mofa.conimes.com;
pvep.scvhosts.com; 112.175.79.55;
223.26.55.122; 198.100.97.245

INTELLIGENCE| Adversary-Centric

1

INTELLIGENCE

Understand the adversaries targeting your
Vertical | Company | Geo-Location | Customers

2

Build appropriate defenses to counter/detect
these adversaries

3

Perform other security practices from an
Adversary-centric perspective
Pen Testing (Red Team)
Security Operations Brieﬁngs
Log Review

INTELLIGENCE-DRIVEN SECURITY
INTELLIGENCE| Making it Actionable

1
ACTIONALIZING INTELLIGENCE

Intelligence is diﬃcult to consume
Lots of information to keep straight
New data constantly ﬂowing in (possibly unvetted)

2

Security Operations need to change shis &amp; people

3

Actionable Intelligence

Pass down can’t possibly occur with all indicators

2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-33-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-33-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/75/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-33-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-33-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide34" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:959 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-33" alt="Q&amp;A

Q&amp;A

@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

Q&amp;A section of the

data-cy="slideshow-title">Cyber espionage nation state-apt_attacks_on_the_rise</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd1na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd1na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/Cyphort">Cyphort</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">In the digital age, one of the most effective ways to gather data and information about a potential enemy state is by infiltrating their ranks with malware. This webinar takes a deep drive into advanced persistent threat attacks performed by nation states. We will discuss various actors, government sponsored hackers, such as Duke, Bear, and Panda. Then we will look at malware created, like Regin, Elise, Flame, Equation Group, Babar, OnionDuke, and Dark Hotel.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R11na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R11na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-1" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R12na7f6:" popovertarget=":R12na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R12na7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/leveraging-mitre-attck-speaking-the-common-language/150494688"><span class="sr-only">Leveraging MITRE ATT&amp;CK - Speaking the Common Language</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:1" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Leveraging MITRE ATT&amp;CK - Speaking the Common Language</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Leveraging MITRE ATT&amp;CK - Speaking the Common Language for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd2na7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbd2na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd2na7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd2na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd2na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/erikvanbuggenhout">Erik Van Buggenhout</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">MITRE ATT&amp;CK is quickly gaining traction and is becoming an important standard to use to assess the overall cyber security posture of an organization. Tools like ATT&amp;CK Navigator facilitate corporate adoption and allow for a holistic overview on attack techniques and how the organization is preventing and detecting them. Furthermore, many vendors, technologies and open-source initiatives are aligning with ATT&amp;CK. Join Erik Van Buggenhout in this presentation, where he will discuss how MITRE ATT&amp;CK can be leveraged in the organization as part of your overall cyber security program, with a focus on adversary emulation.

Erik Van Buggenhout is the lead author of SANS SEC599 - Defeating Advanced Adversaries - Purple Team Tactics &amp; Kill Chain Defenses. Next to his activities at SANS, Erik is also a co-founder of NVISO, a European cyber security firm with offices in Brussels, Frankfurt and Munich.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R12na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R12na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-2" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R13na7f6:" popovertarget=":R13na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R13na7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/cyber-threat-intelligence-its-not-just-about-the-feeds/175890216"><span class="sr-only">Cyber Threat Intelligence - It&#x27;s not just about the feeds</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:2" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Cyber Threat Intelligence - It&#x27;s not just about the feeds" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/bsidesperthcyberthreatintelligence-itsnotjustaboutthefeeds-published1-190925074844-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Cyber Threat Intelligence - It&#x27;s not just about the feeds</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Cyber Threat Intelligence - It&#x27;s not just about the feeds for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd3na7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbd3na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd3na7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd3na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd3na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/IainDickson1">Iain Dickson</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses cyber threat intelligence and how it can support defensive cyber operations. It defines cyber threat intelligence and outlines different data source types that can be used, including internal incident data and external threat intelligence. It describes the Lockheed Martin Cyber Kill Chain and Diamond Models for structuring threat information and identifying gaps. Actionable threat intelligence requires both internal and external data across the cyber kill chain phases to generate useful context. Threat intelligence can help with incident response, penetration testing, and establishing an intelligence-led defensive posture focused on the most relevant threats.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R13na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R13na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-3" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R14na7f6:" popovertarget=":R14na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R14na7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/you-cant-stop-the-breach-without-prevention-and-detection/67472196"><span class="sr-only">You Can&#x27;t Stop The Breach Without Prevention And Detection</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:3" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="You Can&#x27;t Stop The Breach Without Prevention And Detection" Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="You Can&#x27;t Stop The Breach Without Prevention And Detection" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/forrestercrowdstrike10-161020200043-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">You Can&#x27;t Stop The Breach Without Prevention And Detection</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save You Can&#x27;t Stop The Breach Without Prevention And Detection for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd4na7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbd4na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd4na7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd4na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd4na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses the need for a balanced approach to endpoint security that includes both prevention and detection. It argues that relying solely on prevention is not sufficient, as attacks will always get through, requiring detection capabilities to identify breaches. Likewise, detection alone is insufficient, as preventing attacks upfront reduces workload. The document outlines the key components needed to properly unify next-generation antivirus and endpoint detection and response, including complete visibility of endpoint activity, large-scale analysis capacity, and the ability to derive insights and indicators of attack from collected data. An integrated approach is advocated that allows prevention and detection to strengthen one another.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R14na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R14na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-4" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R15na7f6:" popovertarget=":R15na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R15na7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/breach-and-attack-simulation-tools/142699152"><span class="sr-only">Breach and attack simulation tools</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:4" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Breach and attack simulation tools" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/breachandattacksimulationtoolsusingpresentationtemplate4x3green01-190429061218-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Breach and attack simulation tools" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/breachandattacksimulationtoolsusingpresentationtemplate4x3green01-190429061218-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Breach and attack simulation tools</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Breach and attack simulation tools for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd5na7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbd5na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd5na7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd5na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd5na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/bdnog">Bangladesh Network Operators Group</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">With the focus on security, most organisations test the security defenses via pen-testing. But what about after the network has been compromised. Is there an Advance Persistent Threat (APT) sitting on the network? Will the defenses be able to detect this?

This talk will discuss some of the open source tools that can help simulate this threat. So as to test the security defenses if an APT makes it onto the network.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R15na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R15na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-5" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R16na7f6:" popovertarget=":R16na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R16na7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/welcome-to-the-world-of-cyber-threat-intelligence/247219270"><span class="sr-only">Welcome to the world of Cyber Threat Intelligence</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:5" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Welcome to the world of Cyber Threat Intelligence" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/dtucti101andreassfakianakis-210428100549-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Welcome to the world of Cyber Threat Intelligence</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Welcome to the world of Cyber Threat Intelligence for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd6na7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbd6na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd6na7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd6na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd6na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/asfakian">Andreas Sfakianakis</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Title: Welcome to the world of Cyber Threat Intelligence!


Abstract: Welcome to the world of Cyber Threat Intelligence (CTI)! During this presentation, we will discuss about some of the basic concepts within CTI domain and we will have a look at the current threat landscape as observed from the trenches. The presentation is split into 3 parts: a) Intro to CTI, b) A view at the current threat landscape, and c) CTI analyst skillset.


Short Bio: Andreas Sfakianakis is a Cyber Threat Intelligence and Incident Response professional and works for Standard and Poors&#x27; CTI team. He is also a member of ENISA’s CTI Stakeholders’ Group and Incident Response Working Group. He is the author of a number of CTI reports and an instructor of CTI. In the past, Andreas has worked within the Financial and Oil &amp; Gas sectors as well as an external reviewer for European Commission. Andreas&#x27; Twitter handle is @asfakian and his website is www.threatintel.eu </span></div></div><div class="" id=":R16na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R16na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-6" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R17na7f6:" popovertarget=":R17na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R17na7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/infocyte/the-new-pentest-rise-of-the-compromise-assessment"><span class="sr-only">The New Pentest? Rise of the Compromise Assessment</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:6" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="The New Pentest? Rise of the Compromise Assessment" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/compromiseassessmentbh-fin-180814152657-180814160747-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="The New Pentest? Rise of the Compromise Assessment" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/compromiseassessmentbh-fin-180814152657-180814160747-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">The New Pentest? Rise of the Compromise Assessment</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save The New Pentest? Rise of the Compromise Assessment for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd7na7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbd7na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd7na7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd7na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd7na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/infocyte">Infocyte</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">If an attacker had a foothold in your network today, would you know it?

If they made it past your real-time defense measures (EDR, EPP, AV, UEBA, firewalls, etc.) or an analyst misinterpreted a critical alert, chances are they&#x27;ve entrenched themselves for the long haul. Skilled and organized attackers know long-term persistence in your network is the most critical component to meeting their goal of stealing information, causing damage, or pivoting attacks on other organizations. 

Threat hunting is the proactive practice of finding attackers in your environment before they can cause damage (or at least stop the bleeding from continued exposure). Unfortunately, effective threat hunting practices remain out-of-reach for most organizations due to lack of security infrastructure and qualified people to manage advanced endpoint security solutions.

One solution to this problem is to hire a third party to conduct a periodic assessment geared toward discovery of unauthorized access and compromised systems. This is called a &quot;compromise assessment&quot; and just recently compromise assessments have become one of the most requested services from top security service providers. 

Customers don’t want to just know if they can be hacked (a good penetration tester will generally conclude “yes”) they want to know if they ARE hacked—right now—and if so, what endpoints/hosts/servers on their network are compromised.

In this presentation, which was originally prepared for Black Hat 2018, Chris Gerritz outlines the growing practice of compromise assessments and the best practices being utilized by some of the largest and most sophisticated managed security service providers (MSSPs) with this offering. 

What approaches are most effective?
What data is being utilized?
What are some of the top challenges?

To request a free 100-node compromise assessment or to learn more about Infocyte HUNT — our comprehensive threat hunting platform — and start a free trial, please visit https://try.infocyte.com.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R17na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R17na7f6"></div><div class="separator SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Threat intelligence is information that informs enterprise defenders of adversarial elements to stop them.
It is information that is relevant to the organization, has business value, and is actionable.
If you having all data and feeds then data alone isn’t intelligence.

slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MatthewDunwoody1">Matthew Dunwoody</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Every IR presents unique challenges. But - when an attacker uses PowerShell, WMI, Kerberos attacks, novel persistence mechanisms, seemingly unlimited C2 infrastructure and half-a-dozen rapidly-evolving malware families across a 100k node network to compromise the environment at a rate of 10 systems per day - the cumulative challenges can become overwhelming. This talk will showcase the obstacles overcome during one of the largest and most advanced breaches Mandiant has ever responded to, the novel investigative techniques employed, and the lessons learned that allowed us to help remediate it.

Details a massive intrusion by Russian APT29 (AKA CozyDuke, Cozy Bear)</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R19na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" and Red Teams - B Sides San Antonio - Albe... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdcna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdcna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdcna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdcna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdcna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/denimgroup">Denim Group</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">You’ve heard of black, white, and gray box testing? Adding to the security color spectrum, Red Teams (pen testers) working together with Blue Teams (defenders), can improve organizational security and get the most out of security assessments. This talk will discuss both general and specific concepts and techniques to improve penetration tests with coordination of internal security teams. We will discuss high level topics such as knowing  what type of assessment is needed for your organization, to more detailed technical concepts such as detecting attack traffic and coordinating with red team attacks. If your internal security team isn&#x27;t ready for a pentest, lets discuss steps to get your team prepared and ready to fully take advantage of full scope penetration tests. From a pentester perspective, we will discuss the types of testing that is most beneficial to your clients and how to communicate and perform testing activities in conjunction with blue teams. We will also talk about ways to assist the teams with remediation from a 3rd party point of view.
 
What are the three key points an audience will receive:
·      Pen testing techniques on working with internal security
·      Internal security techniques for detecting attacks
·      Concepts on performing the best type of pen test for your customers</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1cna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1cna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-12" aria-haspopup="dialog" ATT&amp;CKcon 2018: Hunters ATT&amp;CKing with the Data, Roberto Rodriguez, Spe...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" with the Data, Roberto Rodriguez, Spe..." src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/2018mitreattckconrodriguez-181116142308-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon 2018: Hunters ATT&amp;CKing with the Data, Roberto Rodriguez, Spe...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon 2018: Hunters ATT&amp;CKing with the Data, Roberto Rodriguez, Spe... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbddna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbddna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbddna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbddna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbddna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/attackcon2018">MITRE - ATT&amp;CKcon</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">With the development of the MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework and its categorization of adversary activity during the attack cycle, understanding what to hunt for has become easier and more efficient than ever. However, organizations are still struggling to understand how they can prioritize the development of hunt hypothesis, assess their current security posture, and develop the right analytics with the help of ATT&amp;CK. Even though there are several ways to utilize ATT&amp;CK to accomplish those goals, there are only a few that are focusing primarily on the data that is currently being collected to drive the success of a hunt program. 

This presentation shows how organizations can benefit from mapping their current visibility from a data perspective to the ATT&amp;CK framework. It focuses on how to identify, document, standardize and model current available data to enhance a hunt program. It presents an updated ThreatHunter-Playbook, a Kibana ATT&amp;CK dashboard, a new project named Open Source Security Events Metadata known as OSSEM and expands on the “data sources” section already provided by ATT&amp;CK on most of the documented adversarial techniques. 
</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1dna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1dna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-13" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1ena7f6:" popovertarget=":R1ena7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1ena7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/cyber-kill-chain/45742703"><span class="sr-only">Cyber kill chain</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:13" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Cyber kill chain</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Cyber kill chain for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdena7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdena7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdena7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdena7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdena7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/ankitaganguly08">Ankita Ganguly</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The cyber kill chain describes cyber attacks from an attacker&#x27;s perspective through distinct phases: (1) reconnaissance, (2) weaponization, (3) delivery, (4) exploitation, (5) installation, (6) command and control, and (7) actions on objectives. Each phase of the kill chain can be mapped to defensive tools and actions to prevent attacks. Understanding the kill chain stages gives analysts insight into what is being attempted and how to respond appropriately. The kill chain was developed by Lockheed Martin as a method to describe intrusions and prevent advanced persistent threats by highly trained adversaries targeting sensitive information.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ena7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1ena7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-14" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1fna7f6:" popovertarget=":R1fna7f6:" for Improving Security Posture in Orga...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:15" Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Adversary Emulation and Its Importance for Improving Security Posture in Orga... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdgna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdgna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdgna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdgna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdgna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/digitoktavianto">Digit Oktavianto</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses adversary emulation and its importance for improving security posture. It begins with an introduction to adversary emulation, comparing it to simulation. Adversary emulation involves closely mimicking the actual tactics, techniques, and procedures of a known adversary based on threat intelligence. The document outlines the benefits of adversary emulation, such as helping organizations test their defenses against the latest real-world threats. It also provides guidance on developing an adversary emulation plan, including researching a specific adversary and modeling their behaviors to design scenario-based tests that are executed sequentially.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1gna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1gna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf Where You Are</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:16" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img Action with What You Have, Where You Are</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Putting MITRE ATT&amp;CK into Action with What You Have, Where You Are for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdhna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdhna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdhna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdhna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdhna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/KatieNickels">Katie Nickels</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document provides an overview of Katie Nickels&#x27; presentation on putting MITRE ATT&amp;CK into action using available resources. Some key points include:
- MITRE ATT&amp;CK is a knowledge base of adversary tactics and techniques based on real-world observations. 
- It can be used for detection, assessment, threat intelligence, and adversary emulation.
- For detection, ATT&amp;CK can help improve focus on post-exploit activity and track gaps/improvements in coverage over time. Existing data sources can be leveraged to detect techniques.
- For assessment and engineering, ATT&amp;CK can guide decisions around tool selection and help identify visibility and risk acceptance gaps.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1hna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1hna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdina7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdina7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses using storytelling to increase understanding of cyber threats through ATT&amp;CK threat sightings. It describes the AC3 methodology for documenting threat actor tactics, techniques, and procedures with full context and observables. Different levels of abstraction and tools are used to translate threat sightings into various formats to ensure understanding across audiences. Maintaining defensive playbooks adapted from threat sightings helps continuous understanding and improvement of defenses.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ina7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1ina7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" Hands-on</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses threat hunting techniques using Splunk, including an overview of threat hunting basics, data sources for threat hunting, and Lockheed Martin&#x27;s Cyber Kill Chain model. It provides examples of using endpoint data to hunt for threats across the kill chain by analyzing processes, communications, and file artifacts in a demo dataset. Advanced techniques discussed include hunting for SQL injection attacks and lateral movement.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1kna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" CrowdStrike</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:20" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">How to Replace Your Legacy Antivirus Solution with CrowdStrike</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save How to Replace Your Legacy Antivirus Solution with CrowdStrike for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdlna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdlna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdlna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdlna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdlna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/abarrera31">Adam Barrera</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The Time Has Come To Replace Your Antivirus Solution

After decades of frustration and failure, the security industry is ready to replace legacy antivirus systems with more effective solutions. As breaches continue to make headlines, we are left to wonder if anything can really stop modern threats. The answer is yes, but it requires us to approach the problem in a new way. Instead of continually adding functionality and complexity to legacy security architectures, we need a complete reset. This is exactly what CrowdStrike offers with its cloud-delivered endpoint protection platform.

The key to this new approach is going beyond malware to understanding and address cyber threats at every stage of the kill chain. CrowdStrike does this by combining next-gen antivirus, endpoint detection and response (EDR), and a managed threat hunting service – all cloud-delivered with a single lightweight agent.

In this CrowdCast, Dan Larson, Sr. Director of Technical Marketing, will discuss:
- The typical challenges with legacy antivirus implementations and how we solve them
- How CrowdStrike offers a greater level of protection, especially against modern threats
- How cloud-delivered endpoint protection reduces operational burden
- How to migrate from legacy antivirus to CrowdStrike Falcon

Link to on-demand webcast: https://www.crowdstrike.com/resources/crowdcasts/time-come-replace-antivirus-solution/</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1lna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1lna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" class="sr-only">NotPetya Report</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:21" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">NotPetya Report</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save NotPetya Report for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdmna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdmna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdmna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdmna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdmna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/BillyWoody">Billy Woody</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document analyzes the NotPetya malware attack of June 2017. It provides technical details on the malware&#x27;s characteristics and behavior. Upon infection, NotPetya encrypts files and renders systems unbootable, displaying a ransom note. However, even if ransom is paid, files cannot be recovered as data and systems were destroyed. NotPetya spread rapidly through Ukraine and globally, infecting thousands of organizations and causing over $10 billion in damages. Recommended containment strategies include backups, patching systems, and restricting administrator privileges and SMB ports.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1mna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1mna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Lex Crumpton leads MITRE&#x27;s defensive ATT&amp;CK efforts. In 2021, they added data sources and detections for monitoring processes interacting with LSASS.exe and detecting credential dumping tools. In 2022, they plan to add more detections and develop the Cyber Analytic Repository to share analytic knowledge. class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">How to Detect a Cryptolocker Infection with AlienVault USM</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save How to Detect a Cryptolocker Infection with AlienVault USM for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdqna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdqna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdqna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdqna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdqna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/alienvault">AlienVault</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">As an IT security pro, unless you&#x27;ve been hiding under a rock, you&#x27;ve heard about ransomware threats like Cryptolocker. These threats are typically delivered via an e-mail with a malicious attachment, or by directing a user to a malicious website. Once the Cryptolocker file executes and connects to the command and control server, it begins to encrypt files and demands payment to unlock them. As a result, detecting infection quickly is key to limiting the damage.

AlienVault USM uses several built-in security controls working in unison to detect ransomware like Cryptolocker, usually as soon as it attempts to connect to the command and control server. Join us for a live demo showing how AlienVault USM detects these threats quickly, saving you valuable time in limiting the damage from the attack.

You&#x27;ll learn:

How AlienVault USM detects communications with the command and control server
How the behavior is correlated with other signs of trouble to alert you of the threat
Immediate steps you need to take to stop the threat and limit the damage</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1qna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1qna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document provides an overview of the Wazuh open source host-based intrusion detection system (HIDS). It describes how Wazuh uses agents installed on endpoints that collect and transmit security data to a central server for analysis. The server analyzes the data, triggers alerts for threats or anomalies, and stores the information in Elasticsearch for visualization and exploration through the Wazuh dashboard user interface. Key components of the Wazuh architecture include the agents, server, indexer cluster for data storage, and dashboard for monitoring, analysis and management.</span></div></div><div class="" threat environment, adversaries are constantly profiling and attacking your corporate infrastructure to access and collect your intellectual property, proprietary data, and trade secrets. Now, more than ever, Threat Intelligence is increasingly important for organizations who want to proactively defend against advanced threat actors.

While many organizations today are collecting massive amount of threat intelligence, are they able to translate the information into an effective defense strategy?

View the slides now to learn about threat intelligence for operational purposes, including real-world demonstrations of how to consume intelligence and integrate it with existing security infrastructure.

Learn how to prioritize response by differentiating between commodity and targeted attacks and develop a defense that responds to specific methods used by advanced attackers.</span></div></div><div loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">No Easy Breach DerbyCon 2016</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save No Easy Breach DerbyCon 2016 for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd1c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd1c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd1c9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd1c9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd1c9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MatthewDunwoody1">Matthew Dunwoody</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Every IR presents unique challenges. But - when an attacker uses PowerShell, WMI, Kerberos attacks, novel persistence mechanisms, seemingly unlimited C2 infrastructure and half-a-dozen rapidly-evolving malware families across a 100k node network to compromise the environment at a rate of 10 systems per day - the cumulative challenges can become overwhelming. This talk will showcase the obstacles overcome during one of the largest and most advanced breaches Mandiant has ever responded to, the novel investigative techniques employed, and the lessons learned that allowed us to help remediate it.

Details a massive intrusion by Russian APT29 (AKA CozyDuke, Cozy Bear)</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R11c9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R11c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div Albe...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:3" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Cyber Purple Teaming: Uniting Blue and Red Teams - B Sides San Antonio - Albe...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Cyber Purple Teaming: Uniting Blue and Red Teams - B Sides San Antonio - Albe... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd4c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd4c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd4c9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd4c9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd4c9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/denimgroup">Denim Group</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">You’ve heard of black, white, and gray box testing? Adding to the security color spectrum, Red Teams (pen testers) working together with Blue Teams (defenders), can improve organizational security and get the most out of security assessments. This talk will discuss both general and specific concepts and techniques to improve penetration tests with coordination of internal security teams. We will discuss high level topics such as knowing  what type of assessment is needed for your organization, to more detailed technical concepts such as detecting attack traffic and coordinating with red team attacks. If your internal security team isn&#x27;t ready for a pentest, lets discuss steps to get your team prepared and ready to fully take advantage of full scope penetration tests. From a pentester perspective, we will discuss the types of testing that is most beneficial to your clients and how to communicate and perform testing activities in conjunction with blue teams. We will also talk about ways to assist the teams with remediation from a 3rd party point of view.
 
What are the three key points an audience will receive:
·      Pen testing techniques on working with internal security
·      Internal security techniques for detecting attacks
·      Concepts on performing the best type of pen test for your customers</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R14c9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R14c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-4" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R15c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R15c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R15c9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/mitre-attckcon-2018-hunters-attcking-with-the-data-robert-rodriguez-specterops-and-jose-luis-rodriguez-student/123180368"><span class="sr-only">MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon 2018: Hunters ATT&amp;CKing with the Data, Roberto Rodriguez, Spe...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:4" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon 2018: Hunters ATT&amp;CKing with the Data, Roberto Rodriguez, Spe..." src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/2018mitreattckconrodriguez-181116142308-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/2018mitreattckconrodriguez-181116142308-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon 2018: Hunters ATT&amp;CKing with the Data, Roberto Rodriguez, Spe...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon 2018: Hunters ATT&amp;CKing with the Data, Roberto Rodriguez, Spe... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd5c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd5c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd5c9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd5c9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd5c9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/attackcon2018">MITRE - ATT&amp;CKcon</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">With the development of the MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework and its categorization of adversary activity during the attack cycle, understanding what to hunt for has become easier and more efficient than ever. However, organizations are still struggling to understand how they can prioritize the development of hunt hypothesis, assess their current security posture, and develop the right analytics with the help of ATT&amp;CK. Even though there are several ways to utilize ATT&amp;CK to accomplish those goals, there are only a few that are focusing primarily on the data that is currently being collected to drive the success of a hunt program. 

This presentation shows how organizations can benefit from mapping their current visibility from a data perspective to the ATT&amp;CK framework. It focuses on how to identify, document, standardize and model current available data to enhance a hunt program. It presents an updated ThreatHunter-Playbook, a Kibana ATT&amp;CK dashboard, a new project named Open Source Security Events Metadata known as OSSEM and expands on the “data sources” section already provided by ATT&amp;CK on most of the documented adversarial techniques. 
</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R15c9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R15c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-5" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R16c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R16c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R16c9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/cyber-kill-chain/45742703"><span class="sr-only">Cyber kill chain</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:5" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Cyber kill chain" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/cyberkillchain-150312035941-conversion-gate01-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Cyber kill chain" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/cyberkillchain-150312035941-conversion-gate01-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Cyber kill chain</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Cyber kill chain for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd6c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd6c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd6c9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd6c9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd6c9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/ankitaganguly08">Ankita Ganguly</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The cyber kill chain describes cyber attacks from an attacker&#x27;s perspective through distinct phases: (1) reconnaissance, (2) weaponization, (3) delivery, (4) exploitation, (5) installation, (6) command and control, and (7) actions on objectives. Each phase of the kill chain can be mapped to defensive tools and actions to prevent attacks. Understanding the kill chain stages gives analysts insight into what is being attempted and how to respond appropriately. The kill chain was developed by Lockheed Martin as a method to describe intrusions and prevent advanced persistent threats by highly trained adversaries targeting sensitive information.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R16c9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R16c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-6" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R17c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R17c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R17c9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/ArpanRaval2/introduction-to-mitre-attck"><span class="sr-only">Introduction to MITRE ATT&amp;CK</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:6" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Introduction to MITRE ATT&amp;CK" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/introductiontomitreattck-200328091951-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Introduction to MITRE ATT&amp;CK" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/introductiontomitreattck-200328091951-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Introduction to MITRE ATT&amp;CK</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Adversary Emulation and Its Importance for Improving Security Posture in Orga... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd8c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd8c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd8c9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd8c9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd8c9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/digitoktavianto">Digit Oktavianto</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses adversary emulation and its importance for improving security posture. It begins with an introduction to adversary emulation, comparing it to simulation. Adversary emulation involves closely mimicking the actual tactics, techniques, and procedures of a known adversary based on threat intelligence. The document outlines the benefits of adversary emulation, such as helping organizations test their defenses against the latest real-world threats. It also provides guidance on developing an adversary emulation plan, including researching a specific adversary and modeling their behaviors to design scenario-based tests that are executed sequentially.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R18c9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R18c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Putting MITRE ATT&amp;CK into Action with What You Have, Where You Are for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd9c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd9c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd9c9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span
