class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd9c9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd9c9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/KatieNickels">Katie Nickels</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document provides an overview of Katie Nickels&#x27; presentation on putting MITRE ATT&amp;CK into action using available resources. Some key points include:
- MITRE ATT&amp;CK is a knowledge base of adversary tactics and techniques based on real-world observations. 
- It can be used for detection, assessment, threat intelligence, and adversary emulation.
- For detection, ATT&amp;CK can help improve focus on post-exploit activity and track gaps/improvements in coverage over time. Existing data sources can be leveraged to detect techniques.
- For assessment and engineering, ATT&amp;CK can guide decisions around tool selection and help identify visibility and risk acceptance gaps.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R19c9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R19c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses threat hunting techniques using Splunk, including an overview of threat hunting basics, data sources for threat hunting, and Lockheed Martin&#x27;s Cyber Kill Chain model. It provides examples of using endpoint data to hunt for threats across the kill chain by analyzing processes, communications, and file artifacts in a demo dataset. Advanced techniques discussed include hunting for SQL injection attacks and lateral movement.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1cc9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1cc9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-12" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1dc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R1dc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1dc9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" CrowdStrike</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:12" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/crowdstrikeavcrowdcast-170103190216-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">How to Replace Your Legacy Antivirus Solution with CrowdStrike</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save How to Replace Your Legacy Antivirus Solution with CrowdStrike for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbddc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbddc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbddc9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbddc9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbddc9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/abarrera31">Adam Barrera</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The Time Has Come To Replace Your Antivirus Solution

After decades of frustration and failure, the security industry is ready to replace legacy antivirus systems with more effective solutions. As breaches continue to make headlines, we are left to wonder if anything can really stop modern threats. The answer is yes, but it requires us to approach the problem in a new way. Instead of continually adding functionality and complexity to legacy security architectures, we need a complete reset. This is exactly what CrowdStrike offers with its cloud-delivered endpoint protection platform.

The key to this new approach is going beyond malware to understanding and address cyber threats at every stage of the kill chain. CrowdStrike does this by combining next-gen antivirus, endpoint detection and response (EDR), and a managed threat hunting service – all cloud-delivered with a single lightweight agent.

In this CrowdCast, Dan Larson, Sr. Director of Technical Marketing, will discuss:
- The typical challenges with legacy antivirus implementations and how we solve them
- How CrowdStrike offers a greater level of protection, especially against modern threats
- How cloud-delivered endpoint protection reduces operational burden
- How to migrate from legacy antivirus to CrowdStrike Falcon

Link to on-demand webcast: https://www.crowdstrike.com/resources/crowdcasts/time-come-replace-antivirus-solution/</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1dc9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1dc9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-13" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1ec9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R1ec9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1ec9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/notpetya-report/125296998"><span class="sr-only">NotPetya Report</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:13" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="NotPetya Report" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">NotPetya Report</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save NotPetya Report for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdec9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdec9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdec9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdec9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdec9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/BillyWoody">Billy Woody</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document analyzes the NotPetya malware attack of June 2017. It provides technical details on the malware&#x27;s characteristics and behavior. Upon infection, NotPetya encrypts files and renders systems unbootable, displaying a ransom note. However, even if ransom is paid, files cannot be recovered as data and systems were destroyed. NotPetya spread rapidly through Ukraine and globally, infecting thousands of organizations and causing over $10 billion in damages. Recommended containment strategies include backups, patching systems, and restricting administrator privileges and SMB ports.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ec9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1ec9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Lex Crumpton leads MITRE&#x27;s defensive ATT&amp;CK efforts. In 2021, they added data sources and detections for monitoring processes interacting with LSASS.exe and detecting credential dumping tools. In 2022, they plan to add more detections and develop the Cyber Analytic Repository to share analytic knowledge. Crumpton invites attendees to learn more about defensive ATT&amp;CK on their website and contact them directly with any other questions.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1hc9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1hc9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">How to Detect a Cryptolocker Infection with AlienVault USM</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save How to Detect a Cryptolocker Infection with AlienVault USM for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdic9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdic9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdic9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdic9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdic9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/alienvault">AlienVault</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">As an IT security pro, unless you&#x27;ve been hiding under a rock, you&#x27;ve heard about ransomware threats like Cryptolocker. These threats are typically delivered via an e-mail with a malicious attachment, or by directing a user to a malicious website. Once the Cryptolocker file executes and connects to the command and control server, it begins to encrypt files and demands payment to unlock them. As a result, detecting infection quickly is key to limiting the damage.

AlienVault USM uses several built-in security controls working in unison to detect ransomware like Cryptolocker, usually as soon as it attempts to connect to the command and control server. Join us for a live demo showing how AlienVault USM detects these threats quickly, saving you valuable time in limiting the damage from the attack.

You&#x27;ll learn:

How AlienVault USM detects communications with the command and control server
How the behavior is correlated with other signs of trouble to alert you of the threat
Immediate steps you need to take to stop the threat and limit the damage</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ic9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1ic9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-18" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1jc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R1jc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1jc9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/wazuh-security-platform/258387376"><span class="sr-only">Wazuh Security Platform</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K Platform" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/wazuh-230613032757-7960a729-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Wazuh Security Platform</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Wazuh Security Platform for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdjc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdjc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdjc9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdjc9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdjc9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/penguinarmy">Pituphong Yavirach</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document provides an overview of the Wazuh open source host-based intrusion detection system (HIDS). It describes how Wazuh uses agents installed on endpoints that collect and transmit security data to a central server for analysis. The server analyzes the data, triggers alerts for threats or anomalies, and stores the information in Elasticsearch for visualization and exploration through the Wazuh dashboard user interface. Key components of the Wazuh architecture include the agents, server, indexer cluster for data storage, and dashboard for monitoring, analysis and management.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1jc9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1jc9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-19" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1kc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R1kc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1kc9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/road-map-for-actionable-threat-intelligence/40558240"><span class="sr-only">Road map for actionable threat intelligence</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:19" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Road map for actionable threat intelligence" class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Road map for actionable threat intelligence</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Road map for actionable threat intelligence for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdkc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdkc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdkc9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdkc9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdkc9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/abhisheksinghcs">abhisheksinghcs</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document outlines a roadmap for developing an effective actionable threat intelligence program. It discusses what threat intelligence is, how it can enable businesses, and provides recommendations for collecting intelligence from internal and external sources. The roadmap involves initially developing a foundation, then formalizing processes, and moving toward maturity with a goal of demonstrating return on investment from averted threats.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1kc9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1kc9jnf6"></div></div><div class="desktop-recs"><div href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">In today’s threat environment, adversaries are constantly profiling and attacking your corporate infrastructure to access and collect your intellectual property, proprietary data, and trade secrets. Now, more than ever, Threat Intelligence is increasingly important for organizations who want to proactively defend against advanced threat actors.

While many organizations today are collecting massive amount of threat intelligence, are they able to translate the information into an effective defense strategy?

View the slides now to learn about threat intelligence for operational purposes, including real-world demonstrations of how to consume intelligence and integrate it with existing security infrastructure.

Learn how to prioritize response by differentiating between commodity and targeted attacks and develop a defense that responds to specific methods used by advanced attackers.</span></div></div><div SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document summarizes a CrowdStrike webinar on detecting advanced malware-free intrusions. It describes three speakers from CrowdStrike - Dmitri Alperovitch, Chris Scott, and Adam Meyers. The webinar then discusses how adversaries like China and various state-sponsored and criminal groups are adapting their tactics to evade detection, and how security teams must also adapt detection methods to focus on real-time monitoring rather than indicators of compromise. The webinar includes a case study of detecting a webshell attack in near real-time using CrowdStrike Falcon Host and concludes with a demonstration of its endpoint protection capabilities.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R13cajnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R13cajnf6"></div><div class="separator Huq</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses cyber threats facing the mining industry. It notes that the mining industry, like other industries, is increasingly relying on integrated and automated systems, leaving it vulnerable to cyber attacks. The mining industry deals with targeted cyber espionage campaigns and disruptive attacks aimed at exploiting its strategic role in global supply chains. The document provides an overview of modern mining operations and infrastructure, noting their complexity and geographical distribution, before examining specific cybersecurity issues and threats.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R14cajnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R14cajnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="similarTo-card-description-4" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R15cajnf6:" popovertarget=":R15cajnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R15cajnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/FrankBackes/cybersecurity-a-community-approach-20151109"><span class="sr-only">Cybersecurity A Community Approach - It identifies several military and academic institutions in Colorado Springs related to cybersecurity and divides the cybersecurity market into five submarkets - consumer/small business, business/enterprise, industrial, military/intelligence, and ethical offensive cyber. Attribution of Russian Intelligence Operations</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Bear Hunting: History and Attribution of Russian Intelligence Operations for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd9cajnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd9cajnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd9cajnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd9cajnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd9cajnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Learn about the history of Russian intelligence influence operations and the cyber actors implementing them today.

In June 2016, CrowdStrike exposed unprecedented efforts by Russian intelligence services to interfere in the U.S. election via the hacking and subsequent leaking of information from political organizations and individuals. Election manipulation was not a new activity for the Russians - they have engaged in these influence operations consistently for the better part of the last two decades inside and outside of Russia.

In this CrowdCast, CrowdStrike experts Adam Meyers, VP of Intelligence, and Dmitri Alperovitch, Co-Founder &amp; CTO, will provide a detailed overview of the history of Russian intelligence influence operations going back decades and provide a deep dive overview of various BEAR (including FANCY BEAR AND COZY BEAR) intrusion sets and their tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs). They will also discuss the considerable attribution evidence that CrowdStrike has collected from a variety of investigations into their operations and lay out the case for the Russian government connection to these hacks.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R19cajnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R19cajnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">SOCRadar 2024 Canada Threat Landscape Report</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save SOCRadar 2024 Canada Threat Landscape Report for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdacajnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdacajnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdacajnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdacajnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdacajnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/socradar">SOCRadar</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Canada’s cybersecurity risks are escalating, with finance and insurance industries making up 12.66% of dark web targets. Ransomware attacks continue to threaten the manufacturing sector, representing 21.11% of cases. LockBit leads the ransomware groups, responsible for 30.3% of attacks. Additionally, stealer logs expose over 208,000 email-password combinations, putting critical systems and sensitive data at risk.

Phishing threats have surged, with cryptocurrency-related attacks comprising 31.66% of incidents. Meanwhile, Canada faced over 110,000 DDoS attacks, signaling the urgent need for organizations to bolster defenses. Threat actors are increasingly leveraging stolen credentials and targeting vulnerable industries.

SOCRadar’s proactive threat intelligence solutions empower Canadian organizations to stay ahead of evolving cyber threats. Detect dark web activities, mitigate ransomware risks, and safeguard your assets with real-time monitoring. Download the full CISO brief now to secure your organization’s future.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1acajnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1acajnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="similarTo-card-description-10" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1bcajnf6:" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdbcajnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdbcajnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/lkcyber">lkcyber</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">RSA Quick Look Webcast: http://www.rsaconference.com/media/quick-look-proactive-counterespionage-as-a-part-of-business-continuity-and-resiliency

This white paper corresponds to the RSA Presentation entitled: &quot;Proactive Counterespionage as a Part of Business Continuity and Resiliency&quot;
Presentation Abstract: The session will discuss means in which information assets and business continuity is protected and propose an additional layer of defense with a human counterespionage focus. The proposed proactive counterespionage plan includes operational security audits, reverse open source intelligence and classification of employees who are prime targets for disruptive espionage. - See more at: http://www.rsaconference.com/events/ad15/agenda/sessions/2219/proactive-counterespionage-as-a-part-of-business#sthash.DTYlHe6a.dpuf</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1bcajnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1bcajnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" aria-describedby="similarTo-card-description-11" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1ccajnf6:" popovertarget=":R1ccajnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1ccajnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/common-good-digital-framework-204737401/204737401"><span class="sr-only">COMMON GOOD DIGITAL FRAMEWORK</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:11" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">COMMON GOOD DIGITAL FRAMEWORK</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save COMMON GOOD DIGITAL FRAMEWORK for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdccajnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdccajnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdccajnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdccajnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdccajnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/bostonglobalforum">Boston Global Forum</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The Common Good Digital Framework (CGDF) is a proposed campaign and platform to monitor violations of ethical values and standards related to artificial intelligence, personal data, cyber security, and digital activity by governments and large organizations. The CGDF will focus on issues like AI bias, privacy, and cyber security, and will generate policy recommendations in response to identified problems. It will utilize partners, advisors, and social media to distribute its findings and recommendations in order to influence policymaking and encourage corrective actions. The goal is to establish new ethical norms and regulations to help guide digital progress for the benefit of all humanity.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ccajnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1ccajnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbddcajnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbddcajnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/bodaceacat">bodaceacat</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses the evolution of misinformation and proposes a framework called AMITT (Attribution, Mitigation, Incident and Technique Taxonomy) to analyze misinformation campaigns and incidents. It suggests populating the AMITT framework by cataloging historical misinformation examples. Finally, it notes that further work is needed to develop mitigations and counters, refine techniques, and share intelligence using the framework.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1dcajnf6:" Barrett</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This overview is not intended to be a business case for data science. It is expected that you are already familiar with the value proposition. However, a reference to several case study examples has been included at the end of this document as a reminder of the broad applicability of the subject at hand.

The intent of this document is to set in motion the discussion for the creation of a startup in South Africa that is focused on data science.  </span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ecajnf6:" data-cy="slideshow-title">SOCRadar-Australia-Threat Landscape-Report-2024.pdf</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save SOCRadar-Australia-Threat Landscape-Report-2024.pdf for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdfcajnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdfcajnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdfcajnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdfcajnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdfcajnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/socradar">SOCRadar</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The 2024 Australia Threat Landscape Report by SOCRadar dives into the evolving cyber threats impacting Australia&#x27;s key industries, focusing on ransomware, phishing, and Dark Web activities. Key findings include:

Ransomware Surge: A substantial increase in ransomware incidents, especially from groups like Medusa, LockBit 3.0, and Akira, targeting sectors such as retail and healthcare.
Dark Web Exposure: Australian organizations are heavily featured in Dark Web data sales, with notable activity against the retail and finance sectors.
Phishing and DDoS Attacks: The rise in phishing attacks and record-breaking DDoS incidents underscores the sophistication of current cyber threats.
The report offers strategic recommendations for organizations to enhance cybersecurity resilience, leveraging SOCRadar’s Extended Threat Intelligence, which includes tools for proactive threat detection, Dark Web monitoring, and brand protection.

Get insights from the full report to safeguard your assets and strengthen cyber defenses in Australia’s challenging digital landscape.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1fcajnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1fcajnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" Threat Landscape Report by SOCRadar dives into the evolving cyber threats impacting Australia&#x27;s key industries, focusing on ransomware, phishing, and Dark Web activities. Key findings include:

Ransomware Surge: A substantial increase in ransomware incidents, especially from groups like Medusa, LockBit 3.0, and Akira, targeting sectors such as retail and healthcare.
Dark Web Exposure: Australian organizations are heavily featured in Dark Web data sales, with notable activity against the retail and finance sectors.
Phishing and DDoS Attacks: The rise in phishing attacks and record-breaking DDoS incidents underscores the sophistication of current cyber threats.
The report offers strategic recommendations for organizations to enhance cybersecurity resilience, leveraging SOCRadar’s Extended Threat Intelligence, which includes tools for proactive threat detection, Dark Web monitoring, and brand protection.

class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:16" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Forrester   no more chewy centers- the zero trust model</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Forrester   no more chewy centers- the zero trust model for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdhcajnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdhcajnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdhcajnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdhcajnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdhcajnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/cgarcia045">Cristian Garcia G.</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document summarizes John Kindervag&#x27;s report &quot;No More Chewy Centers: The Zero Trust Model Of Information Security&quot;. The report argues that traditional perimeter-based network security models are ineffective against modern threats like targeted attacks and malicious insiders. It introduces the &quot;Zero Trust&quot; model, which considers all network traffic untrusted and requires strict access controls and monitoring. The report recommends security professionals adopt this new model to better protect their organizations from sophisticated adversaries inside and outside the network.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1hcajnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1hcajnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/mok">Charles Mok</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses emerging security issues related to fake news, AI, and privacy. It summarizes recent regulations on facial recognition in the US, UK, and EU. It also discusses misinformation campaigns related to protests in Hong Kong and how Twitter and Facebook have taken actions to suspend accounts spreading misinformation. The document explores how misinformation can be spread through deepfake videos and AI-generated fake news. It discusses efforts to combat fake news through fact checking and provides examples from Hong Kong and Taiwan. Finally, it calls for the IT industry to adopt an approach that puts people first, develops privacy-enabled technologies, and promotes openness and public awareness.</span></div></div><div class="" RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Where is endpoint security headed? How do your priorities and capabilities compare to those of your peers?

As the battle against breaches rages on, many enterprises are focused on revamping their endpoint security strategy – from enhancing efficacy to reducing complexity and agent bloat. A new webcast, “State of the Endpoint: The Buyer Mindset,” discusses the current state of endpoint security and offers insights from an all-star panel of thought leaders, including Internationally recognized cybersecurity leader and CrowdStrike Co-founder Dmitri Alperovitch, VP of Product Marketing Dan Larson, and other experts as they discuss today’s most important security issues. Join them as they explore the findings from a new research report, “Trends in Endpoint Security: A State of Constant Change,” a study conducted by ESG and commissioned by CrowdStrike and other technology vendors. The panel will provide their impressions of the data in the survey and how the viewpoints revealed mesh with current technology trends, offering insights that can help inform your security strategy going forward.

Join this webcast to learn:

-The current state of Antivirus (AV) including how many organizations are choosing to change vendors and why
-Best of breed vs. comprehensive suites – which approach do your peers prefer and what are the advantages and challenges of each?
-How solutions are affecting endpoints and your IT Security peers, including the increase in agents installed and the impact of increased complexity</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R11cbjnf6:" RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">How adversaries use fileless attacks to evade your security and what you can do about it

Standard security solutions have continued to improve in their ability to detect and block malware and cyberattacks. This has forced cybercriminals to employ stealthier methods of evading legacy security to achieve success, including launching fileless attacks, where no executable file is written to disk. Download this presentation provided by CrowdStrike security experts to learn why so many of today’s adversaries are abandoning yesterday’s malware and relying on an evolving array of fileless exploits. 

You’ll learn how fileless attacks are conceived and executed and why they are successfully evading the standard security measures employed by most organizations. You’ll also receive guidance on the best practices for defending your organization against these stealthy, damaging attacks.

The following presentation includes:
--How a fileless attack is executed — see how an end-to-end attack unfolds
--Why fileless attacks are having so much success evading legacy security solutions
--How you can protect your organization from being victimized by a fileless attack, including the security technologies and policies that are most effective</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R12cbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R12cbjnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Real world lessons from CrowdStrike Services experts investigating complex cyber extortion attacks

The criminal act of theft is as old as civilization itself, but in the cyber realm new ways to steal your organization&#x27;s data or profit by holding it hostage, continue to evolve. With each advancement in security technology, adversaries work tirelessly on new techniques to bypass your defenses. This webcast, &quot;Cyber Extortion: Digital Shakedowns and How to Stop Them&quot; examines the evolution of cyber extortion techniques, including the latest &quot;datanapping&quot; exploits. Whether it&#x27;s an attack on a major movie studio, a massive healthcare system, or a global entertainment platform, recent extortion attempts demonstrate how critical it is to understand today&#x27;s threat landscape so you can ensure that your organization mounts the best defense possible.

Download this presentation to learn what security experts from the cyber defense frontlines are discussing. Learn about:

•The range of extortion techniques being used today, including commonalities and differences in approaches
•Commodity type ransomware/datanapping vs. hands-on attacks — how are they alike and what are their differences?
•Potential outcomes of paying vs. not paying when attempting to recover data after an attack
•Real world examples of successful attacks and those that were thwarted or mitigated
•Strategies for keeping your organization from being targeted and what to do if you become the victim of a cyber shakedown</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R13cbjnf6:" popover="manual" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Gain in-depth information on the massive WannaCry ransomware attack

On Friday, May 12, the WannaCry ransomware variant swept the globe. In a short period of time, WannaCry (also known as Wanna Decryptor and WannaCryptor) infected over 230,000 systems in 150 countries. It was a particularly effective piece of malware because it not only encrypted data and held it for ransom, but it also spread like wildfire to other systems. Entire organizations found themselves looking at a ransom note on their screens and wondering what to do next.

As the situation continues to unfold, please join us as Adam Myers, VP of Threat Intelligence at CrowdStrike, presents an in-depth look at the WannaCry ransomware.

Register for this webcast to learn:
-A complete technical understanding of the WannaCry threat
-What analysts were seeing on the day of the WannaCry outbreak
-How to prevent WannaCry infections and protect against ransomware going forward</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R14cbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" OverWatch Experts Hunt 24/7 To Stop Incidents Before They Become Breaches

Is your IT security team suffering from alert fatigue? For many organizations, chasing down every security alert can tax an already overburdened IT department, often resulting in a breach that might have been avoided. Adding to this challenge is an increase in sophisticated threats that strike so fast and frequently, traditional methods of investigation and response can’t offer adequate protection. 

A new webcast from CrowdStrike, “Proactive Threat Hunting: Game-Changing Endpoint Protection Above and Beyond Alerting,” discusses why so many organizations are vulnerable to unseen threats and alert fatigue, and why having an approach that is both reactive and proactive is key. You’ll also learn about Falcon OverWatch™, CrowdStrike’s proactive threat hunting service that investigates and responds to threats immediately, dramatically increasing your ability to react before a damaging breach occurs.

Download the webcast slides to learn:

--How constantly reacting to alerts prevents you from getting ahead of the potentially damaging threats designed to bypass standard endpoint security
--Why an approach that includes  proactive threat hunting, sometimes called Managed Detection and Response, is key to increasing protection against new and advanced threats   
--How CrowdStrike Falcon OverWatch can provide 24/7 managed threat hunting, augmenting your security efforts with a team of cyber intrusion detection analysts and investigators who proactively identify and prioritize incidents before they become damaging breaches

If your organization has moved to a Mac-based platform, or are considering it, you may be aware that threats targeting Mac devices are on the rise. A new webcast from CrowdStrike, &quot;Defending Against Threats Targeting the Mac Platform&quot; discusses how the increase in Mac adoptions has given rise to a new class of targeted threats and explains why standard security solutions can&#x27;t protect you.

In this CrowdCast, Peter Ingebrigtsen, as discussed why more companies are switching to the Mac platform, the new threats targeting Macs, and what you can do to better protect your organization.

Download the slides to learn:
Why more IT departments are switching to the Mac platform
How new threats targeting Macs are able to bypass standard security measures
How CrowdStrike&#x27;s next-gen AV employs machine learning and behavioral analytics to defend against threats aimed at the Mac platform

Ransomware Morphing Beyond The Ability Of Standard ...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:6" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="CrowdStrike CrowdCast: Is Ransomware Morphing Beyond The Ability Of Standard ..." slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">CrowdStrike CrowdCast: Is Ransomware Morphing Beyond The Ability Of Standard ...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save CrowdStrike CrowdCast: Is Ransomware Morphing Beyond The Ability Of Standard ... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd7cbjnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd7cbjnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd7cbjnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd7cbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd7cbjnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Learn how to prevent &amp; detect even the most complex “file-less” ransomware exploits

Ransomware continues to evolve as perpetrators develop new exploits with consequences that can be dramatic and immediate. The purveyors of ransomware continue to prosper with adversaries developing new strains such as Zepto and Cerber that are proving to be more challenging than ever. Other exploits can alter programmable logic controller (PLC) parameters and adversely impact mechanical systems. Clearly, new defense approaches are needed because organizations can no longer rely on backups and conventional security solutions to protect them. Join CrowdStrike Senior Security Architect Dan Brown as he offers details on these sophisticated new ransomware threats, and reveals recent innovations designed to offer better protection – including new indicator of attack (IOA) behavioral analysis methodologies that can detect and prevent even the most complex “file-less” ransomware exploits.

Attend this CrowdCast where Dan will discuss:
--The challenges of defending against dangerous new variants, such as Zepto and Cerber
--Real-world examples of ransomware in action and the sophisticated tactics being used by a variety of adversaries
--How the CrowdStrike Falcon cloud-delivered platform can defend your organization against new super strains of ransomware that use sophisticated malware-free tactics
</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R17cbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R17cbjnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime CrowdStrike</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:7" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document summarizes CrowdStrike&#x27;s endpoint security product Falcon and argues that it provides more effective protection than legacy antivirus solutions. It notes that antivirus has an efficacy rate of only 45% against modern threats and is ineffective at stopping sophisticated attacks. CrowdStrike&#x27;s Falcon uses techniques like machine learning, IOAs, and threat intelligence to prevent a wider range of attacks while having a smaller system footprint than antivirus. It also provides detection capabilities like endpoint detection and response to eliminate attack dwell time. The document aims to convince readers to replace their legacy antivirus with CrowdStrike&#x27;s Falcon.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R18cbjnf6:" popover="manual" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">As the cost and complexity of deploying and maintaining on-premises security continues to rise, many endpoint security providers have embraced the cloud as the ideal way to deliver their solutions. Yet, incorporating cloud services into legacy architectures limits their ability to fully engage the tremendous power the cloud offers.

CrowdStrike Falcon recognized the value of cloud-delivery from the beginning, developing architecture built from the ground up to take full advantage of the cloud. CrowdStrike’s cloud-powered endpoint security not only ensures rapid deployment and infinite scalability, it increases your security posture by enabling real-time advanced threat protection across even the largest, distributed enterprises.

In this CrowdCast, Jackie Castelli, Sr. Product Manager will discuss:

•The advantages of endpoint protection purpose-built for the cloud – why it allows you to take full advantage of the cloud’s power
•The common concerns organizations face when evaluating cloud-based endpoint security - can privacy and control be assured?
•Real-world examples demonstrating the unique advantages    offered by CrowdStrike Falcon’s innovative cloud-powered platform</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R19cbjnf6:" popover="manual" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses how machine learning can be used to battle unknown malware. It provides examples of using machine learning techniques like feature selection, dimensionality reduction, and classification on military personnel data and malware samples. While machine learning is effective against most malware, it is not enough on its own as many attacks do not use malware. A comprehensive prevention approach is needed to address the full spectrum of threats.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1acbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1acbjnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="moreFromUser-card-description-10" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1bcbjnf6:" popovertarget=":R1bcbjnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1bcbjnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike/java-journal-pyresso-a-pythonbased-framework-for-debugging-java"><span class="sr-only">Java Journal &amp; Pyresso: A Python-Based Framework for Debugging Java</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Java Journal &amp; Pyresso: A Python-Based Framework for Debugging Java for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdbcbjnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdbcbjnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdbcbjnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdbcbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdbcbjnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Despite the multitude of Java decompilers available, we often have the need to debug or trace malicious or obfuscated Java bytecode. Existing Java debuggers and tracers are mostly targeted towards Java developers, are closed-source, and are not meant to handle malicious or obfuscated targets. We present a new open-source cross-platform framework for debugging Java, written completely in Python, designed specifically for reverse engineering. We also present a Java method call tracer as a sample Python application that utilizes this framework.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1bcbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1dcbjnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="moreFromUser-card-description-13" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1ecbjnf6:" popovertarget=":R1ecbjnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1ecbjnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/crowd-cast-monthly-mitigating-pass-the-hash/26618483"><span class="sr-only">CrowdCasts Monthly: Mitigating Pass the Hash</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:13" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="CrowdCasts Monthly: Mitigating Pass the Hash" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/crowdcastmonthlymitigatingpassthehash-130927085734-phpapp01-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">CrowdCasts Monthly: Mitigating Pass the Hash</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save CrowdCasts Monthly: Mitigating Pass the Hash for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdecbjnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdecbjnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdecbjnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdecbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdecbjnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Sixteen years later and Pass the Hash (PtH) is still one of the most common techniques a targeted attacker can use to compromise a network. There have been many blogs, webinars, and papers covering different PtH mitigation strategies. With all the information about this particular security vulnerability, networks are still continuously attacked and infiltrated using this technique. It is time to look at the problem from a holistic approach and apply the communities&#x27; collective intelligence to make this process one of the most difficult for a targeted attacker to use. </span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ecbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1ecbjnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="moreFromUser-card-description-14" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1fcbjnf6:" popovertarget=":R1fcbjnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1fcbjnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/endtoend-analysis-of-a-domain-generating/25244628"><span class="sr-only">End-to-End Analysis of a Domain Generating Algorithm Malware Family</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:14" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="End-to-End Analysis of a Domain Generating Algorithm Malware Family" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/end-to-endanalysisofadomaingeneratingalgorithmmalwarefamily-slides-130814103104-phpapp02-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">End-to-End Analysis of a Domain Generating Algorithm Malware Family</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save End-to-End Analysis of a Domain Generating Algorithm Malware Family for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdfcbjnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdfcbjnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdfcbjnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdfcbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdfcbjnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document summarizes the analysis of a domain generating algorithm (DGA) malware family. Key points include:

- The malware uses inline code obfuscation and encrypted strings to hide its functionality and communication domains. Researchers were able to deobfuscate the code and decrypt the strings to analyze the malware. 

- Clues in decrypted strings suggest the malware author is Romani, including references to Romani singers in template strings. 

- The malware generates domain names by concatenating two randomly selected words from a dictionary and appending &quot;.net&quot;. This allows it to generate many domain variations to communicate with its command and control servers.

- The DGA algorithm uses a 15-bit seed value derived from the</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1fcbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1fcbjnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="moreFromUser-card-description-15" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1gcbjnf6:" popovertarget=":R1gcbjnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1gcbjnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/tor-all-the-things/25244568"><span class="sr-only">TOR... ALL THE THINGS</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:15" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="TOR... ALL THE THINGS" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/tor-130814102922-phpapp02-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="TOR... ALL THE THINGS" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/tor-130814102922-phpapp02-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">TOR... ALL THE THINGS</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save TOR... ALL THE THINGS for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdgcbjnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdgcbjnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdgcbjnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdgcbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdgcbjnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The global Tor network and its routing protocols provide an excellent framework for online anonymity. However, the selection of Tor-friendly software for Windows is sub-par at best. 

Want to anonymously browse the web? You’re stuck with Firefox, and don’t even think about trying to anonymously use Flash. Want to dynamically analyze malware without letting the C2 server know your home IP address? You’re outta luck. Want to anonymously use any program that doesn’t natively support SOCKS or HTTP proxying? Not gonna happen. 

While some solutions currently exist for generically rerouting traffic through Tor, these solutions either don’t support Windows, or can be circumvented by malware, or require an additional network gateway device. 

Missed the live session at Black Hat USA 2013? Check out the slides from Jason Geffner&#x27;s standing room only presentation! Jason released a free new CrowdStrike community tool to securely, anonymously, and transparently route all TCP/IP and DNS traffic through Tor, regardless of the client software, and without relying on VPNs or additional hardware or virtual machines.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1gcbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1gcbjnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="moreFromUser-card-description-16" aria-haspopup="dialog" Malware Family Whitepaper</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:16" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdhcbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdhcbjnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document provides an overview of domain generating algorithms (DGAs) used by malware to dynamically determine remote server addresses and evade detection. It details the analysis performed on a malware family submitted to CrowdStrike, including deobfuscating the binary, analyzing its DGA and network functionality, sinkholing domains, and investigating the malware author. The family has been active for at least six years and infects thousands of devices.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1hcbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1hcbjnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="moreFromUser-card-description-17" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1icbjnf6:" popovertarget=":R1icbjnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1icbjnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/tor-all-the-things-whitepaper/25207431"><span class="sr-only">TOR... ALL THE THINGS Whitepaper</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:17" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="TOR... ALL THE THINGS Whitepaper" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/tor-130813094128-phpapp02-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">TOR... ALL THE THINGS Whitepaper</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save TOR... ALL THE THINGS Whitepaper for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdicbjnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdicbjnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdicbjnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdicbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdicbjnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document introduces Tortilla, software designed to allow security researchers to safely and anonymously interact with hostile servers and actors online. It discusses how traditional malware research was more passive, but now requires actively monitoring adversary infrastructure. The Tor network and Tor Browser Bundle are described as existing solutions for anonymity, but they have limitations like only supporting the Firefox browser and not plugins. Tortilla aims to address these issues by providing a more robust anonymity solution.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1icbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1icbjnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdjcbjnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdjcbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdjcbjnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses a technique for regaining control of a disk in the presence of a bootkit by leveraging the crash dump stack in Windows. It provides background on the crash dump stack and how it differs from the normal I/O path. It then describes how identifying and calling the crash dump port and miniport drivers allows sending I/O requests outside of the normal path to bypass bootkit filters and read/write directly to disk. The document concludes with an overview of how this technique can be demonstrated against the TDL4 bootkit.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1jcbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1jcbjnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="moreFromUser-card-description-19" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1kcbjnf6:" popovertarget=":R1kcbjnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1kcbjnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/hacking-exposed-live-mobile-targeted-threats/14360141"><span class="sr-only">Hacking Exposed Live: Mobile Targeted Threats</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:19" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Hacking Exposed Live: Mobile Targeted Threats</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Hacking Exposed Live: Mobile Targeted Threats for later" role="switch" class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdkcbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdkcbjnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document introduces CrowdStrike speakers George Kurtz, Georg Wicherski, and Alex Radocea. It then discusses the evolution of threats from commercial remote access tools (RATs) to targeted RATs and advanced threats. Examples of commercial RATs like FlexiSPY and targeted RATs like LuckyCat are analyzed. The feasibility of developing exploits and native Android RATs is also explored.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1kcbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start"
